rubric.name: Academic Objectivity
rubric.description: Writing should maintain an objective, research-appropriate tone that avoids subjective or emotional language.
rubric.evidence: User explicitly rejected the adjective 'hard-won' stating 'this is a research paper' and accepted the change from 'feel' to 'appear' for more objective phrasing.

rubric.name: Literal Over Metaphorical Language
rubric.description: Writing should use direct, literal descriptions rather than metaphorical or figurative expressions.
rubric.evidence: User explicitly rejected the metaphorical phrase 'fragmented landscape of AI interactions' in favor of the straightforward listing 'models, sessions, and tasks'.

rubric.name: Neutral Descriptive Language
rubric.description: Writing should use emotionally neutral terms that describe rather than evaluate or dramatize.
rubric.evidence: User consistently accepted removal of evaluative terms like 'hard-won' and 'evaporates' in favor of neutral alternatives 'calibration' and 'does not persist'.

rubric.name: Concise Expression
rubric.description: Writing should favor simple, direct phrasing over elaborate or complex constructions.
rubric.evidence: User accepted simplified phrasing throughout, including 'requiring' over 'forcing' and direct lists over elaborate descriptions.

rubric.name: Selective Precision
rubric.description: Writing should be targeted and precise, adding only necessary elements rather than comprehensive rewrites.
rubric.evidence: User stated 'I think we just need the last sentence rather than all the sentences' indicating preference for minimal, focused changes over extensive revisions.

rubric.name: Technical Accuracy
rubric.description: Writing should maintain precise technical terminology and concepts appropriate to the subject matter.
rubric.evidence: User maintained technical terms throughout the conversation (conversational memory, alignment, calibration) and did not request simplification of specialized vocabulary.
